poem_title: A Description of Bath. Humbly Inscribed to Her Royal Highness the Princess Amelia.
author: Mary Chandler
poem_alt_title: Humbly Inscribed to Her Royal Highness the Princess Amelia .

lines.line_text: , beauteous , deign to view
What the  sings: to  the Song is due;
To , in whom with Joy we see combin'd
True  Greatness, and an  Mind.
Deign , bright Maid, to hear my artless Lays;
You'll awe the snarling Critics into Praise.
If Goodness can this bold Address forgive,
Nurs'd by your Smiles, my humble Rhymes shall live.

lines.line_text: sing the Town, where balmy Waters flow,
To which  Health the Nations owe,
My Muse aspires; while conscious Blushes rise,
And her weak Pinions tremble, ere she flies;
Till, drawing Vigour from those living Springs,
She dares to raise her Voice, and stretch her Wings.
Not the fam'd Springs, which gave Poetic Fire,
Had nobler Virtues, or could more inspire.
Too weak my Voice; but Great  Name
Shall raise my Numbers, and defend my Fame.

lines.line_text: ere the  Eagle hither flew,
Ere  Sons their pow'rful Virtues knew;
great Descendant rais'd them first to Fame,
And, from their Use, assign'd the Town its Name.
he chose Protectress of the Streams,
the City her Protectress claims;
Thus He, who of Man's Fall divinely sings,
Tells from old Records, wrote of  Kings.
The  well this ancient Story knew,
Statues their Devotion drew;
Of curious Art her noble  appears,
Safe from the Ruin of a thousand Years.
These salutary Streams alone can boast
Their Virtues not in thrice five Ages lost.
The floating Waters, from their hidden Source,
Thro' the same  keep unerring Course;
The flowing  meets dissolving ,
And heat in , till the Waters boil:
then, enrich the healing Stream,
to the  they give, and to the , .

lines.line_text: so, O  bland! when rul'd by thee,
The  obedient, and the  is free:
Soft are his , balmy is his ,
His  not boiling from the ;
Touch'd by  rosy Hand, he wakes,
Peaceful and calm; and with the World partakes
The joyful Dawnings of returning Day,
For which their grateful Thanks the whole Creation pay!
All but the ; 'Tis he alone
Whose Deeds of Darkness fly the rising Sun.

lines.line_text: by the  winding Streams,
Beneath the Hills, a peopled Island seems;
An antient  in its Center stands,
The labour'd Work of superstitious Hands.
When  supreme did guide the Helm,
And  overspread the Realm;
The  amaz'd the gaping Croud,
And  was veil'd in  Cloud;
When  for  bled;
And  were offer'd to the ;
When  Devotion drew,
And  were worshipp'd as the ;
Witness yon ; how impiously design'd
In  to represent th' !
Witness the  and  on the !
to their Vot'ries , and  to their .
Welcome, fair , and  !
Yet  spread your Wings, and brighter shine;
Dart  Beams on ev'ry  Soul,
And scatter  to the Pole.
Now for  is the  design'd;
O that the Muse cou'd say to  confin'd!
Ev'n there, by , and ,
The  her  knows!
Fly hence, , nor taint this Sacred Place;
Mock not thy GOD, to flatter  Face.
This Sacred Pile incloses honour'd Dust,
And pompous  secure the Trust:
There , the Noble Prelate, lies,
With pious Hands up-lifted to the Skies:
A  here enjoys eternal Fame,
Join'd on the Marble with Great  Name.

lines.line_text: far from hence, a  of  Heat,
The  finds a safe
From  indecent, and from  lewd,
Which dare not there, with , intrude.
Just in the midst a  there stands,
Which Popish Minds with pious Awe commands,
Devoid  of  to heal our Woes,
Yet, deck'd with , shows
What  this wond'rous  has done,
And these the  from  won.
The  thus, on foaming Billows tost,
His , and  in the Tempest lost,
Did some kind God's assisting Pow'r implore,
And when, by Aid Divine, he reach'd the Shore,
Strait to the Temple of the God he flew,
His briny Coat he thought the Temple's Due:
And near the dropping Garment, on the Wall
He wrote, with grateful Praise, the moving Tale.

lines.line_text: the , I guide my View around,
And mark the  venerable .
Where the Remains of many an hundred Year,
In rev'rend Ruins, on the Walls appear,
A   with snaky Hair there stands;
Here  th'attentive Eye demands;
And there a  and his ;
These Monuments, and more, are known to Fame.
view the ; it forms a verdant ,
See the Trees wanton in the Eastern Air;
gilds them with a temp'rate Ray,
And  shade in Noon of Day.
An  doth now its Center grace,
The latest, proudest, Honour of the Place.
To future Times this Monument shall show,
How much all , and all  owe,
To Springs which sav'd from Death the Great .
From , and beauteous , shall descend,
Heroes like , ready to defend
Fair  oppress'd, and trampled ,
Or die with Pleasure in the glorious Cause.
What less than this can Prophecy divine,
When  Blood is mix'd with  Line?

lines.line_text: the  was wont to skim the ,
Now stately Rooms for Pleasure change the Scene;
Where  warbles, and the  bound,
While the high Roof re-echoes to the Sound.
There blooming Virgins kindle am'rous Fires;
And there the God of Wit with Verse inspires.
The  enchants the  ,
The  the  share:
Th'important Bus'ness of the Fair, ,
Employs those Hours which  cannot kill;
Or fav'rite , sweetly sung by ,
Appalls their  with , or reddens them with .
There  soon learns the Language of the ,
The  looks soft, and swears he dies;
And who can think so  a  lyes?
There , the , and the ,
And all Mankind's  you view.
But fly, my Muse, fly this enchanting Place,
Nor , thro' all his Pleasures, dare to trace.

Of  inclos'd, and  ever green,
Descend to , 'twixt  in adverse Rows,
And view the gay  that ever blows.
This fair  view, around its Base
Observe the Sportings of the .
A cool , the  ,
From , and , a blest Retreat!
The lovely , and the silent ,
Inspire the , and present the Theme.
Round the  the  glides away,
Where 'midst  balmy  play,

And , irregular and rude!

downward from the Mountain's Height,

lines.line_text: here, the Muse shall build thy Seat,
Great like thy , in ev'ry Part complete:
On this fair Eminence the  stands,
The finish'd Labour of a thousand Hands;
The , the , the  and ,
Vary the , which thy  yields;
Whole  of  give our Eyes Delight,
Yet scorn alone to gratify the ;
Beneath the Load the tender Branch shall bend,
And the rich Juice regale its .
Thy Taste refin'd appears in yonder Wood,
Not  tortur'd, but by  improv'd:
Where  with  meet,
An  here, and there a .
A thousand Sweets in mingled Odours flow
From blooming , which on the Borders grow.
In num'rous Streams the murm'ring Waters thrill,
Uniting all, obedient to thy Will;
Till by thy Art, in  combin'd,
They thro' the  in various  wind;
From thence the foaming Waves fall rapid down,
In bold , and lash the rugged Stone.
But here their Fury lost, the calmer Scene
Delights the softer Muse, and Soul serene;
An ample , Center of the Place,
In Lymph transparent holds the scaly Race;
Its glassy Face, from ev'ry Ruffle free,
Reflects the Image of each neighb'ring Tree;
On which the , melodious, throng,
By Love inspir'd, unite in tuneful Song;
Their tuneful Song the echoing  resound,
And falling  add a solemn Sound,
Sure this the Muses haunt; 'tis hallow'd Ground!
Here could the Muse for ever spend her Days,
And chant, in humble Rhymes, the Owner's Praise,
How by his Art, young  shall no more
Her  Letter lost, with Sighs deplore,
Unjustly jealous of her faithful Swain,
Whilst he expects the kind Return in vain.
How from the Mountain's rocky Sides he drew
A thousand shining Palaces to view:
, and  in ev'ry Land,
From Age to Age, his Monuments shall stand.
itself shall die, and fickle ,
When he is dead, do Justice to his Name.
Had I or  Wing, or  Fire;
true Greatness, or soft Lyre;
Could I, like tuneful , command the ;
Did my Verse flow, and as it flows, refine;
Thus would I sing; but O, with Grief I find
My feeble Pen but faintly paints my Mind!
Myself unequal to the great Design,
The Task to abler Poets I resign.
